definitions.definition: to make water, air, gas, etc. flow in a particular direction by using a pump or something that works like a pump

examples.text: The engine is used for pumping water out of the mine.
The heart pumps blood around the body.
It took ages to pump out the cellar *(= pump the water out of it)* after the flood.
The lake had been pumped dry.
His heart pumped harder as he held his breath.
The lungs pump oxygen into the bloodstream.

definitions.definition: to flow in a particular direction as if it is being forced by a pump

examples.text: Blood was pumping out of his wound.
The shock sent adrenalin pumping through her veins.

definitions.definition: to move something quickly up and down or in and out

examples.text: He kept pumping my hand up and down.
I pumped the handle like crazy.

definitions.definition: to move quickly up and down or in and out

examples.text: She sprinted for the line, legs pumping.
My heart was pumping with excitement.

definitions.definition: to try to get information from somebody by asking them a lot of questions

examples.text: See if you can pump him for more details.

definitions.definition: to fire a lot of bullets into somebody
to fill somebody with something, especially drugs

examples.text: They pumped her full of painkillers.

definitions.definition: to do exercises in which you lift heavy weights in order to make your muscles stronger
to remove the contents of somebody’s stomach using a pump, because they have swallowed something harmful

examples.text: He had his stomach pumped after taking an overdose.

wordOrigin: verb late Middle English (originally in nautical use): related to Dutch pomp ‘ship's pump’ (earlier in the sense ‘wooden or metal conduit’), probably partly of imitative origin.
